citation.article-title: Mycobacterium shimoidei sp. nov., nom. nov., a lung pathogen.

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium shimoidei sp. nov., nom. rev.
Mycobacterium shimoidei (shimo.idé.i. M.L. gen. n. shimoidei of Shimoide; named for H. Shimoide, the first to isolate this organism)
Acid-fast rods, 0.5 μm by 3.0 to 5.0 μm; crossbarring ordinarily occurs; cords are not formed; mycelium is not produced.

Forms rough colonies which are not pigmented when grown in the dark or when exposed to light (non-photochromogenic); grows on egg media (Ogawa egg medium and Lowenstein-Jensen medium) after incubation at 37°C for 14 to 21 days (when inoculated as single cells onto egg media, growth occurs after 21 or more days); does not grow on Sauton agar or on Sauton agar containing 0.1% NaNO2 or 0.2% picric acid (no growth on Sauton agar containing 0.1% NaNO2 or 0.2% picric acid shows that the test strains belong to the group of slowly growing mycobacteria [6]); growth at 28°C is variable; growth occurs at 37 and 45°C but not at 52°C.

Grows on Ogawa egg medium (or Lowenstein-Jensen medium) containing 0.2% sodium p-aminosalicylate, rifampin (25 μg/ml), p-nitrobenzoic acid (0.5 mg/ml), sodium salicylate (0.5 mg/ml), or thiophene-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide (10 μg/ ml); does not grow on Ogawa egg medium containing ethambutol (5 μg/ml), NH2OH⋄HCl (0.25 mg/ml), 5% NaC1, or isoniazid (10 μg/ml).

Niacin is not produced; Tween is not hydrolyzed after 7 days but is hydrolyzed after 14 days (strains maintained in laboratories hydrolyze Tween after 7 days); α-esterase negative; pesterase negative; β-galactosidase negative; acid phosphatase positive; catalase (semiquantitative) negative; nitrate not reduced to nitrite after 24 h; arylsulfatase negative after 14 days; nicotinamidase and pyrazinamidase positive (these may be negative with strains tested immediately after isolation from sputum); acetamidase, benzamidase, urease, isonicotinamidase, salicylamidase, allantoinase, and succinamidase negative.

The following carbohydrates are not utilized as a sole source of carbon in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen: acetate, citrate, succinate, malate, pyruvate, benzoate, malonate, fumarate, glucose, fructose, sucrose, mannose, galactose, arabinose, xylose, rhamnose, trehalose, inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, ethanol, n-propanol, n-butanol, isobutanol, propylene glycol, and 1,3-, 2,3-, and 1,4-butylene glycols.

The following nitrogen compounds are not utilized as a sole source of nitrogen in the presence of glycerol: glutamate, serine, methionine, acetamide, benzamide, urea, pyrazinamide, nicotinamide, isonicotinamide, succinamide, nitrate, and nitrite.
L-Glutamate is not utilized as a simultaneous nitrogen and carbon source.
Considered to be pathogenic, causing lung infections in humans.
A culture of this strain has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection, Rockville Maryland, under the number ATCC 27962.
The description of the type strain is the same as that given above for the species.
